sn56.45:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn56.45:4.2: Then Venerable Ānanda got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, entered Vesālī for alms.
sn56.45:4.3: He saw several Licchavi youths practicing archery. They were shooting arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing.
sn56.45:4.4: When he saw this he thought:
sn56.45:4.5: “These Licchavi youths really are trained, so well trained,
sn56.45:4.6: in that they shoot arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing.”
sn56.45:5.1: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Vesālī. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha,
sn56.45:5.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn56.45:5.3: and told him what had happened.
sn56.45:6.1: “What do you think, Ānanda? Which is harder and more challenging:
sn56.45:6.2: to shoot arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing? Or to take a horsehair split into seven strands and penetrate one tip with another tip?”
sn56.45:6.3: “It’s more difficult and challenging, sir, to take a horsehair split into seven strands and penetrate one tip with another tip.”
sn56.45:6.4: “Still, Ānanda, those who truly penetrate suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path penetrate something tougher than that.
sn56.45:7.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
